009
010package imagingbook.common.color.adapt;
011
012import imagingbook.common.color.cie.Illuminant;
013
014import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.inverse;
015import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.multiply;
016
017/**
018 * <p>
019 * This class represents a linear chromatic adaptation transform, mapping XYZ color coordinates from a source white
020 * (reference) point to a target white point. Both white points are passed to the constructor. The actual color mapping
021 * is done by method {@link #applyTo(float[])}. The underlying linear transformation is specified by a 3x3 matrix, which
022 * may be retrieved by {@link #getAdaptationMatrix()}). See Sec. 14.6 of [1] for additional details and examples.
023 * </p>
024 * <p>
025 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer
026 * (2022).
027 * </p>
028 *
029 * @author WB
030 * @version 2022/11/14
031 * @see XYZscalingAdaptation
032 */
033public class BradfordAdaptation implements ChromaticAdaptation {
034        
035        // CAT forward transform matrix from XYZ to "virtual" RGB scaling coordinates
036        private static final double[][] MCAT = {
037            { 0.8951,  0.2664, -0.1614},
038            {-0.7502,  1.7135,  0.0367},
039            { 0.0389, -0.0685,  1.0296}};
040           
041        // CAT inverse transform matrix from "virtual" RGB scaling coordinates back to XYZ
042        private static final double[][] MCATi = inverse(MCAT);    // we always invert for precision reasons
043//              {{ 0.9869929054667120, -0.1470542564209900, 0.1599626516637310}, 
044//               { 0.4323052697233940,  0.5183602715367770, 0.0492912282128560}, 
045//               {-0.0085286645751770,  0.0400428216540850, 0.9684866957875500}}
046        
047        // the complete color adaptation transformation matrix for transforming source XYZ to target XYZ,
048        // XYZ2 = Madapt * XYZ1, with
049        // Madapt = MCAT^-1 * DiagRGB * MCAT
050        private final double[][] Madapt;
051        private final double[][] Mdiag;
052        
053        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
054
055        /**
056         * Returns a {@link BradfordAdaptation} instance for the specified white point coordinates.
057         *
058         * @param W1 source white point (to map from)
059         * @param W2 target white point (to map to)
060         * @return a {@link BradfordAdaptation} instance
061         */
062        public static BradfordAdaptation getInstance(double[] W1, double[] W2) {
063                return new BradfordAdaptation(W1, W2);
064        }
065
066        /**
067         * Returns a {@link BradfordAdaptation} instance for the specified illuminants (white points).
068         *
069         * @param illum1 source illuminant (white point to map from)
070         * @param illum2 target illuminant (white point to map to)
071         * @return a {@link BradfordAdaptation} instance
072         */
073        public static BradfordAdaptation getInstance(Illuminant illum1, Illuminant illum2) {
074                return getInstance(illum1.getXYZ(), illum2.getXYZ());
075        }
076        
077        /** Constructor (non-public) accepting two white points (XYZ-coordinates). */
078        private BradfordAdaptation(double[] W1, double[] W2) {
079                double[] rgb1 = multiply(MCAT, W1);
080                double[] rgb2 = multiply(MCAT, W2);
081                this.Mdiag = getRgbWhiteRatioMatrix(rgb1, rgb2);
082                this.Madapt = multiply(MCATi, multiply(Mdiag, MCAT));
083        }
084        
085        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
086        
087        public static double[][] getMCAT() {
088                return MCAT;
089        }
090        
091        public static double[][] getMCATi() {
092                return MCATi;
093        }
094        
095        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
096        
097        @Override
098        public float[] applyTo(float[] XYZA) {
099                // XYZB = Madapt . XYZA
100                float[] XYZB = new float[3];
101                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
102                        XYZB[i] = (float) (Madapt[i][0] * XYZA[0] + Madapt[i][1] * XYZA[1] + Madapt[i][2] * XYZA[2]);
103                }
104                return XYZB;
105        }
106        
107        @Override
108        public double[] applyTo(double[] XYZA) {
109                // XYZB = Madapt . XYZA
110                double[] XYZB = new double[3];
111                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
112                        XYZB[i] = Madapt[i][0] * XYZA[0] + Madapt[i][1] * XYZA[1] + Madapt[i][2] * XYZA[2];
113                }
114                return XYZB;
115        }
116
117        /**
118         * Returns the composite color adaptation transformation matrix.
119         *
120         * @return the color adaptation transformation matrix
121         */
122        public double[][] getAdaptationMatrix() {
123                return this.Madapt;
124        }
125        
126
127        // Creates a diagonal matrix with the ratios of the rgb components
128        // obtained by transforming the two white points
129        private static double[][] getRgbWhiteRatioMatrix(double[] rgbA, double[] rgbB) {
130                if (rgbA.length != rgbB.length) {
131                        throw new IllegalArgumentException();
132                }
133                final int n = rgbA.length;
134                double[][] M = new double[n][n];
135                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
136                        M[i][i] = rgbB[i] / rgbA[i];
137                }
138                return M;
139        }
140                
141}
